Mrs. Nguyen Thi V., aged 32, became a member of TYM Fund in 1999. Her family’s main source of income is from farming. But besides farming, they also pack bricks to sell. In the first round of loan, Mrs. V. asked for only 1.000.000 VND to buy and sell sands. But after that, Mrs. V. used the loans to buy and sell bricks. As the demand for building materials is enormous these days, Mrs. V.’s business has been very profitable. They make about 4.000.000 VND per month. In the next round of loan, Mrs. V. would like to borrow 10.000.000 VND ($625) to purchase materials to make bricks. Her family’s monthly income is 6.000.000 VND.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khoa Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Services

loans.name: Odina

texts.ru: Алиев Одина житель  города Куляб. Возраст 47 лет, женат , имеет 5 детей. Клиент на местном рынке имеет небольшую торговую точку ,где торгует мясом.Он покупает на местном рынке сельхоз.животных ,откармливает их .После откормки продает их мясо на рынке по более выгодной ему цене. Этот вид деятельности является единственным источником дохода его большой семьи. В данный момент клиент хочет  закупить 3  бычков.Планирует погасить кредит в течении 12 месяцев.
texts.en:
Odina A. resides in the town of Kulob. 47-years-old, he is married and has five children. He has a stall at the local market where he trades in meat. He buys farm animals locally and feeds them. After fattening, he sells the meat for a profit at the market. His business is the sole source of income for his large family. At present he wishes to purchase three steers and plans to repay the loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Joyce K., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of three steers

loans.name: Maria Raquel

texts.en: María Raquel L. is a member of community bank, Anabella, at FINCA Perú. In addition to being an accountant, María also runs her own small grocery store where she works everyday. She plans to invest her loan of 1500 soles into her business to purchase corn, beer and sugar. She is currently saving to purchase Christmas presents, continue increasing her capital and to fill up her store. Her goal is to be able to help her children get an education.

loans.use: Maria plans to purchase corn, beer and sugar.

loans.name: Luz Verónica

texts.es:
La  señora  Luz Verónica tiene 36 años, pertenece al Banco Comunal Dios Guía Nuestros Pasos II y vive en la Avenida 28 de Julio  121 del distrito Florencia de Mora en la provincia de Trujillo en el departamento de la Libertad.
Estudió hasta tercer año de secundaria, se casó de 17 años con el señor Manuel Rodríguez con quien tiene 2 hijos hombres y una mujer. La hija mujer ya está casada, los varones son estudiantes.
Su negocio, consiste en la fabricación de faldas y blusas, las que las envía a Quiruvilca, ciudad de la sierra, donde las vende otra persona. También hace arreglos de ropa a sus conocidos y vecinos.
Con su primer crédito de 300 soles que devolvió en 4 meses compró hilos, telas, adornos, aplicaciones.
Con este crédito de 500 soles que será cancelado en 4 cuotas comprará telas hilo, aplicaciones, entretela, panqueques, etc. 
Luz Verónica sueña con tener una remalladora, para poder confeccionar, polos, buzos, uniformes escolares de tela sintética.
texts.en:
Luz Veronica is 36 years old and she belongs to the Community Bank 'Dios Guia Nuestros Pasos II', and she lives on the 28th of July Avenue in the district of Florencia de Mora in the province of Trujillo in the department of La Libertad.

She studied until the third year of secondary school, and she married Manuel Rodriguez when she was 17, with whom she has 2 boys and a girl. Her daughter is already married and her two sons are still studying.

Her business consists of making shirts and skirts, which she sends to Quiruvilca, a city in the mountains, where someone else sells them. She also makes clothing adjustments and does mending for her friends and neighbors.

With the first credit of 300 soles, that she paid back over a period of 4 months, she bought thread, fabric, patterns and clothing adornments. With this credit of 500 soles, that she will repay in 4 installments, she will buy fabrics, thread, adornments, backing fabric etc

Luz Veronica dreams of having a sewing machine to be able to make polo shirts, track suits, and school uniforms from synthetic fabrics.


Translated from Spanish by Liz Harvey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fabrics, thread, adornments and backing fabric in bulk/Compra de telas, hilos, aplicaciones, entretela, panqueques al por mayor.

loans.name: Faizan Mai Manzoor Ahmad Group

texts.en:
Faizan Mai baji is a 43-year-old woman who lives in Shah Rukn, Pakistan. She owns a two-room brick house where she has been living for the past 10 years. She is the mother of one son who is 19 years old and works in an oil mill, where he packs cooking oil in cans. Faizan baji’s husband,M. A., is an animal seller with 20 years of experience in his business. 

Faizan baji  has a milk business. She has a buffalo at her home and she gets milk from her by getting up early in the morning. She sells the milk in the milk shops and charges 36 Pakistani Rupees for each kilogram of milk. She successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah, a microfinance institute in Pakistan. Now she is applying for a loan to buy another buffalo to expand her milk business. 

She is a the leader of a five-person loan group. Noreen Mai baji wants a loan to buy a buffalo and sell the milk.  Bashiran baji and Sakina Mai baji each want a loan to buy fertilizer to resell. Naseem Mai baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle).  

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Note: "Baji," which means "older sister," is a term of respect for women in Pakistan.

loans.use: To buy a buffalo for her milk business

loans.name: Edith

texts.es: Edith tiene 23 años y vive con sus padres. Ella tiene un gran don para embellecer a las personas, y utiliza esta habilidad para  ganarse la vida en su salón de belleza, el que instaló hace 2 años, siendo dentro de todo, los cortes de cabello, lo que le más le agrada realizar, ya que son éstos los que logran dar a sus clientes una nueva imagen que resalte su atractivo. Edith tiene en su salón de belleza una alternativa para salir de la pobreza en la que vive, y gracias a que  no hay muchos salones de belleza puede atender a gran cantidad de personas. Este es su 7mo préstamo con MFP, y hasta hoy no ha tenido ningún problema en pagar sus cuotas. Con el dinero que solicita implementará su salón de belleza con diversos instrumentos y productos indispensables para seguir trabajando.
texts.en:
Edith is 23 years old and lives with her parents. She has a great gift of making people beautiful. She uses this ability to earn a living in her beauty salon, which she began 2 years ago. She lives giving haircuts since with these, she succeeds in giving her clients a new image that makes them more attractive. Edith has, in her beauty salon, an alternative to the poverty in which she lives. Because there aren’t many beauty salons, she can take care of more people. This is her seventh loan with MFP, and until today she hasn’t had any problem in repaying punctually. With the money that she is requesting, she will stock her beauty salon with many instruments and indispensible products to continue working.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To stock her beauty salon with necessary products

loans.name: Carolina

texts.es: Carolina es madre soltera, vive con sus dos hijos pequeños en la casa de sus abuelos. Se dedica a vender golosinas en un pequeño kiosco que mandó a construir muy cerca de un colegio, esta labor la viene ejerciendo desde hace 2 años atrás y lo que le gusta es que vende diariamente  y sus principales consumidores son los niños que asisten a ese colegio y los que pasan por allí. Le es muy rentable porque aún en época de vacaciones, la calle donde está ubicada es muy transitada, y definitivamente cuando empiezan las clases (marzo a diciembre) le va mucho mejor. Este es su primer préstamo con MFP, esta requiriendo esta cantidad de dinero para comprar mayor cantidad de productos y estar bien surtida para cuando empiecen las clases
texts.en:
Carolina is a single mother who lives in her grandparents’ house with her two young children. She dedicates herself to selling snacks from a small kiosk she had built very close to a school. She has been carrying out this activity for two years and what she enjoys is that she sells on a daily basis. Her primary customers are the children who attend the school and pass near her location. The business is very profitable because, even during the vacation season, the road where she is located is well-traveled. Definitively, when school starts up (March to December), her business does much better. This is her first loan with MFP and the amount she is requesting is to buy products at wholesale so she can be well-stocked when classes start.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase her merchandise supply.

loans.name: Hanro

texts.ru: Хамро женщина в возрасте 52 лет , мать двоих детей , муж на заработках в России.Сама Хамро работает в районом детсаду воспитательницей.Свободное время уделяет уходу за скотом.Откормив скот на продажу на рынок  выводит её сын, ему 20 лет.Так как оплата труда воспитателей очень мизирная то Хамро длагодаря бизнесу животноводства увеличила свой оборотный капитал и улучшила семейную жизнь.
texts.en:
Hamro A. is a 52 year old woman, she is the mother of two children and her husband is away earning money in Russia. Hamro is a daycare teacher at the local daycare. In her free time she tends livestock. After fattening livestock, her son takes it to the market to sell; he is 20 years old. Since daycare teacher salaries are tiny, thanks to her livestock business Hamro increased her working capital and improved the life of her family.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Cattle Feed

loans.name: Chiriuhin

texts.en:
Chiriuhin S. is a farmer who produces vegetables and fruits. Chiriuhin likes his job and enjoys meeting people and offering them his products. He thinks that the most important thing in his job is acquiring loyal customers. This principle has given him very good results. The business he runs is profitable and the loan he would like to obtain from Microinvest will help him continue his business.

Chiriuhin wishes to thank Microinvest and Kiva for assisting with this loan.

loans.use: To continue his vegetable and fruit business

loans.name: Kadamala

texts.en:
Kadamala K. is currently in the business of selling at a hotel and is requesting a loan to buy necessities for the hotel. Kadamala is 32 years old and is married to a teacher. She has three children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services. These are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Buy necessities for the hotel

loans.name: Juana Guadalupe

texts.es:
La señora Juana Guadalupe Y. E. tiene 48 años, vive en el distrito de Salaverry, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
Ella estudió Secretariado Ejecutivo, carrera que ejerció durante 14 años y que abandono cuando la empresa donde trabajaba cerró definitivamente. Tiene un hijo que depende económicamente de ella.
Juana tiene una pequeña librería y una bodega, inicio su negocio vendiendo útiles escolares, luego empezó la venta de vino hace 2 años, el mismo que abandono por que ya no le era muy rentable, con las ganancias obtenidas amplio su negocio con la venta de abarrotes y pudo comprar una vitrina y un andamio para sus productos. Su negocio lo desarrolla en su domicilio. 
Con el primer crédito de 300 soles que recibió de su banco comunal “Jerid Camino al Éxito II”, lo invirtió en la compra de abarrotes.  
Con el crédito de 900 soles, que será cancelado en  6 meses, lo invertirá en la  compra de insumos para la preparación de alimentos, útiles escolares y uniformes.
Juana tiene el gran sueño de construir su casa y tener una bodega más grande.
texts.en:
Señora Juana Guadalupe Y. E. is 48 years of age and lives in the Salaverry District of Trujillo Province, Department of La Libertad, Peru. She studied to become an executive secretary, a career which she practiced for 14 years but which she abandoned when the business where she was working went belly up. She has a son who depends on her financial support. Juana has a small shop where she sells books and groceries. She started her business selling school supplies. Two years ago she began selling wine but gave it up because it was not very profitable. With her earnings she expanded her business to include selling groceries and was able to buy a display case and shelving for her merchandise. She is developing her business in her home. The first loan of 300 Sols which she received from her communal bank (Jerid Camino al Éxito II Communal Bank) was used to buy groceries. With this loan of 900 Sols, which will be repaid in six months, she intends to buy ingredients for preparing meals, school supplies and uniforms. Juana has a great desire to build herself a house and to have a larger store.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Kvaka, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy school supplies and uniforms, and ingredients for preparing meals.

loans.name: Sophia

texts.en:
Sophia G., 32 years old, is married with five children who are currently in school. She has been a local manufacturer of palm oil for three years now. Palm oil is produced from palm nuts, while palm kernel oil is produced from palm kernel. She produces these and supplies them to food vendors for use in food preparation. She normally alternates her production between the two products - in other words, by producing palm oil, she automatically obtains the raw materials with which to produce palm kernel oil.

She wants to use her loan to buy more bags of palm nuts, as well as an electric milling machine to increase efficiency so that she can produce in larger quantities. She believes this will help expand her business to allow her to raise more income, making it possible for her to help her husband provide support for her family and finance their children’s education.

Sophia belongs to a village bank called ‘Nkwa Nsuo,’ which translates literally as "living waters."

loans.use: To buy bags of palm nuts and an electric milling machine.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is happily married to Danny T.. She is 45 years old and has two children: Dennis who is 23 years old and Danica who is 18 years old. Dennis has finished college while Danica still is studying.

Josephine has been a hog raiser in her village for many years. The business contributes a great deal in providing her children with their education. She is hoping to receive a loan of PHP 9,000, which she will use to buy more feed for her hogs.

She hopes to sustain her hog raising while at the same time continuing their rice farming which also helps provide daily necessities, especially in sending their children to school.

loans.use: To buy more feed for her pigs

loans.name: Eleuteria

texts.es:
La señora Eleuteria pertenece al Banco Comunal “Niño Jesús D. Praga”  que esta ubicado en el distrito D. Yunguyo, Provincia D. Chuchito, Departamento D. Puno. Ella tiene 57 años D. edad, está casada y es madre D. 04 hijos todos ya independientes y profesionales.  Tiene estudios D. primaria incompleta (2do grado) y vive en el Barrio Huascar.

Trabaja con el movimiento Manuela Ramos desD. la fundación del Banco Comunal,  con un préstamo inicial D. S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, inició su negocio D. compra y venta D. verduras. 

En este momento ella requiere un préstamo D. S/. 3000.00 Nuevos soles, para poder invertir en su actual negocio, comprará verduras, (zanahorias, apio, lechugas, cebollas, tomates zapallos, los mismos que los compra directamente D. Arequipa para luego venderlos en las ferias D. Yunguyo.

Su mayor sueño es seguir trabajando y tener más ganancias.

A ella le gustan los encuentros entre Bancos Comunales.
texts.en:
Mrs. Eleuteria belongs to the Community Bank "Niño Jesús D. Praga" (Child Jesus of Prague) located in the Yunguyo district, province of Chuchito, department of Puno. She is 57 years old, married and mother of 4 grown children, all independent and professionals. She has completed primary school through the 2nd graD., and lives in the Huascar neighborhood. She has been working with the Manuela Ramos movement since the inception of the Community Bank, with an initial loan of 300 new soles she started her business in the buying and selling of vegetables. She is currently needing a loan of 3000 new soles to invest in her business. She will purchase vegetables, (carrots, celery, lettuces, onions, tomatoes, squashes) which she buys directly from Arequipa and then sells them in the markets of Yunguyo. Her biggest dream is to continue working and have more income. She enjoys the meetings among the member of the Community Banks.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For the purchase of carrots, celery, lettuces.onions, tomatoes squashes for resale.

loans.name: Feliciana

texts.en:
In 2006, Mrs. Feliciana B., 54, set up her food business. She sells food on the streets and viands for lunch, especially to people who don't have time to cook food. All the income that she earns from selling food helps in paying off the utility bills and in meeting the basic needs of her family.

She is asking a loan of PHP 6,000 from CEVI to buy additional ingredients for food vending. She has been thinking of starting some other business to supplement her income. The loan will truly help her grow her business.

Like other entrepreneurs, she is thankful to CEVI for helping her. According to her, the loan that she gets from joining the program of CEVI has strengthened her business. Every week during meetings, she learns different things from other entrepreneurs. CEVI provides its clients not only loans, but also trainings and insurance coverage services.

loans.use: To buy additional ingredients for food vending

loans.name: Margie

texts.en: Margie C. is from the village of Poblacion 1, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 39 years old, married, and has a school-aged child. Margie owns and operates a business making and selling food, primarily preparing and selling barbecued chicken and pork in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 21,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Margie joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. Margie is requesting a new loan of 24,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be her fourth from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Mwanaharusi

texts.en:
Mwanaharusi is a member of Kichangani borrower group in Kola ,Morogoro.she is 35 old woman,she is  married, and a mother of four.  Her children are aged 17, 15, 9, and 6 years. 

Mwanaharusi started her own cafe business selling bites 4 years ago, she works 12 hours a day and earn monthly profit of approximately 150,000 Tanzanian shillings (about $114 US).

This is Mwanaharusi's first loan from BRAC Tanzania.  She requests the amount of 300,000 shillings in order to buy more commodities like rice, wheat, and sugar for her business.  With the profit she gains from the use of this loan Mwanaharusi hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy  wheat,sugar,cooking oil

loans.name: Gloria Marina

texts.es:
Gloria es socia del Banco Comunal Wiñarisun que significa Crezcamos en quechua.
Gloria es conviviente, tiene 36 años y 3 hijos, Gloria tiene un restaurante en un local alquilado llamado Las Tejas, actividad que realiza todos los días con la ayuda de 2 personas. Además Gloria cría cuy en su casa.
Gloria necesita un préstamo de 1250 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de alimento para cuy.
Los sueños de Gloria son tener un recreo en su casa y que sus hijos sean profesionales.

loans.use: Para la compra de alimento para cuy.

loans.name: Jyldyz's Group

texts.en:
Jyldyz is the leader of this group. At the age of thirty-six, she is divorced and raises two daughters on her own. To earn her small family’s living she works in a nursing home as a matron. Both of her daughters go to school, and as they grow, Jyldyz’s monthly salary of $50 has begun to be insufficient to provide everything for her daughters. So Jyldyz has found herself an extra occupation, selling fruits. Her sister has been selling fruits for many years and once advised her to start doing the same. She helped Jyldyz with the first purchase and now this new activity allows Jyldyz to cover her family’s living expenses. Jyldyz has decided to obtain a loan and purchase fruits in a neighboring region in larger quantities and bring them to her town to sell. This way she would be able to earn more money and make a needed repair at her house. Jyldyz is ready to do everything within her capability to provide her daughters with a good college education. In the near future she is going to open a small shop. 

Jyldyz’s partners are: Zamira, Erkingul and Taasil. Zamira, age 43, has raised four children. She is engaged in cattle breeding and her husband is an excavator operator. Her 19-year-old daughter helps Zamira keep house. Zamira needs a loan to purchase fodder and hay for the cattle.

Erkingul, age 26, has two children. Her husband sells flour. Before, he used to receive flour instead of a salary, which he would exchange for cattle. He would then feed and resell them. Now Erkingul is engaged in raising the cattle. Erkingul needs a loan to purchase calves and fodder for them.

Taasil, age 47, has mothered six children. Most of them have left for Russia to work. Her husband works at a construction site and she bakes bread and manufactures traditional articles. Taasil needs a loan to purchase coal, as winter is approaching. 
======================================
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy fruit in a neighboring region in large quantities for resale locally.

loans.name: Erina

texts.en:
Erina is a member of the Idope borrower group in Kinyanambo, Iringa. She is single and a mother of 2 children. Her children are 18, 9 years old.

Erina has owned a  business for 4 years, she works 3 hours a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 300,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Erina`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzanian, she requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more chicken for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Erina hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more chicken for sale

loans.name: Alba Arely

texts.es: Alba Arely I. A. reside en San Juan Opico en el departamento de La Libertad. Alba de 34 años de edad vive con su esposo y sus dos hijos Nelson de 6 anos y Edwin de 2 años. Alba  tiene una tienda ubicada en su casa la cual instalo pensado que era una buena y provechosa manera de  trabajar y a su vez cuidar de sus hijos, en la tiende de Alba se vende variedad de productos para el hogar,  Alba es un persona muy responsable ha manejado dos créditos anteriormente los cuales ha cancelado y fue muy puntual en sus pagos, este nuevo crédito que solicita es para surtir su negocio.
texts.en:
Alba Arely I. A. lives in San Juan Opico in the La Libertad department. Alba, 34, lives with her husband and their two children. Nelson is six, and Edwin is two. Alba has a store, which is located in her house. She set it up thinking that it would be a good and beneficial way to work and take care of her children at the same time. In the store Alba sells a variety of products for the home. Alba is a very responsible person. She has managed two previous loans, which she repaid by making her payments punctually. The new loan she is asking for is to stock her business.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Stock her business

loans.name: Belinda

texts.en:
Belinda manages a livestock business where she raises ducks and sells them for PHP 120 per kilo. Aside from raising ducks, she also sells vegetables in their village and in the public market of Cauayan City.

Belinda decided to request a loan of PHP 4,000 from Kiva lenders as additional capital that she needs to improve her two businesses. She plans to use the loan to make a shelter for her ducks and to provide for their growth. She continuously works hard for the sake of her family to meet their needs.

Belinda is 36 years old and is married to Walter, a farmer. They have four children: Algery, 16 years old, in fourth-year high school; Julius, 14 years old, in third-year high school; Zyra, 5 years old, in preschool; and Amir, 1 year old. They live at Nungnungan, Cauayan City, a rural area. Their house is located along the highway.

loans.use: To build a shelter for her ducks

loans.name: Khuy

texts.en:
Khuy S., 53, is a rice farmer who has been farming since 2004. Currently, he owns a machine which he uses to provide plowing or transporting services for a fee. He is married with two single children who both work as teachers. His wife sells a few fish in the market to earn a living and is also a good homemaker who cooks tasty meals for the family.

Khuy S. is running his business smoothly but unfortunately his farming machine is often broken which affects his income. Because of this problem, Khuy S. is applying for a loan to repair his machine.

Note: Khuy S. was busy at work, so his wife is in the photo instead.

loans.use: To repair his farming machine

loans.name: Sonia

texts.en:
Sonia T. is from the village of Barangay Uno. She is 33 years old. Sonia is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Sonia owns & operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Sonia has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Sonia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Sonia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from PMPC. Sonia is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Sonia from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business and support the education of her children.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Wani

texts.en:
E. Wani sells soft drinks, such as soda, water, and juice. She is requesting a loan to stock beer and wines to sell. Wani is 34 years old and is married to a plumber. She has 3 children who go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a bar.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock beer and wines to sell.

loans.name: Abekundire Group, Ibanda

texts.en: Isaiah K. is 55 years old and married with 5 children of school age, and he also takes care of 3 dependants. Isaiah has a grocery and farming business in Bufunda Street that he has owned for over 20 years, and he is able to make 400,000/= in profits per month from both businesses. With the good customer care skills that he provides to his clients, he has been able to succeed, especially with the additional help from the loans he has previously received. He hopes to see his children educated to the highest level of education as his businesses continues to grow. Isaiah needs a loan to help restock his business as he is a friendly and cooperative man.

loans.use: To buy more pesticides and fertilizers for his farm, and buy more products for his grocery store.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Purchase of shellfish, shrimp, and fish.

loans.name: Cesar

texts.en:
Cesar G. is from the village of Salay, Misamis Oriental. He is 34 years old. Cesar is married and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, Cesar owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling seafood products, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. Cesar has been engaged in his business for over two years and earns approximately $75 a month from this activity.

In 2009, Cesar joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation by engaging in business activities. Cesar is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding his business. This will be his 1st loan from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding his business

loans.name: Francoise

texts.en:
Francoise is 35 years old and single. Francoise takes care of five dependents between the ages of 5 and 14. These dependents are relatives. This big family lives in Nyarugenge District in the Kigali Province in the village called Gitega where her business is located. Francoise has a business selling cow meat. She has 15 years of experience in this business. Her business is open every day from 6:00 in the morning to 6:00 in the evening. 

Francoise is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company to expand her business by purchasing more meat to sell. In fact, Francoise does not have enough money to invest, so she is requesting a loan. The profits Francoise expects to earn will help her to reinvest in her business. This will allow her to sort out her family problems.

loans.use: To buy more cow meat to sell

loans.name: Irenia

texts.en:
Irenia Arnaiz is requesting for a loan through ASHI for the second time yet first time through Kiva.  This loan will be used to purchase another hog for fattening.  She wanted to sell her hogs after four months to make more profit.  

She also wanted to invest some portion of her loan in a rice production business managed by her husband, with the help of her eldest son.  Irenia also plans to raise chicken in their backyard. Her livestock will be sold to people within their village either alive or slaughtered.  Her rice will be sold in volume to the vendors.  

Proceeds of these businesses will be used to support the needs of her family, especially to improve their way of living.  Aside from her desire to support her children, Irenia wants to support the needs of her grandchildren by making her business profitable.

loans.use: Purchase hog/pig and necessary farm inputs.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita G. is from the village of Brgy. Nangalisan, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 37 years old. Teresita is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Teresita owns & operates a general store selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Teresita has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Teresita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 16,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Teresita is requesting a new loan of 19,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be the seventh loan taken out by Teresita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Channa

texts.en:
Mrs. Channa E. (in the photo) and her husband Mr. Chhorn Cheng, live on an Island of Mekong River, about fifteen kilometres from Phnom Penh, were married in 1988 and have four children, three sons and one daughter. Three of their children are in school and the youngest one stays at home.

Mrs. Channa has been a silk weaver for more than twenty years, a skill she learned from her mother. She also started a new business selling silk products. She buys silk fabrics from weavers in her village and transports them to sell in other provinces far away from her house. Her husband has been a construction worker since 1993.

Mrs. Channa has received loans from Kiva before, and is now requesting a loan of US$500 to purchase silk fabrics for resale.

loans.use: To purchase silk fabrics for resale.

loans.name: Leonardo

texts.en:
Leonardo S. is from the village of Olango. He is 44 years old. Leonardo is married and has 7 school-aged children. To make a living, he plants and harvests rice for sale. Leonardo has been engaged in his business for over 21 years and earns approximately $1300 a month for these activities.

In 2008, Leonardo joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leonardo has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. 

Leonardo is requesting a new loan of 24,000 PHP which again will be used to purchase fertilizers. This will be his 5th loan from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of his children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Nida

texts.en: Nida, a 45-year-old mother of four children in Agusan Del Sur, is able to sustain her family through rice farming. Her farming income enables her to send her children to school. Nida is requesting a loan of Php 7,000 from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to help her to buy farm supplies.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is 38 years and single. She is the mother of three children aged between sixteen and one and a half years. She runs a cafeteria in Nairobi. She has requested a loan of Kes. 20,000 to buy sugar, rice, beans, baking powder, maize flour and wheat flour to make the food for her cafeteria. Mary dreams of expanding her business, opening more outlets, and growing it into a hotel. Her loan is guaranteed by her group members.

loans.use: To buy sugar, rice, beans, baking powder, maize flour and wheat flour

loans.name: Margret

texts.en: Margret J. is currently in the business of selling tomatoes, onions, cooking oil and sweet potatoes and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of onions to sell. Margret is 39 years old and is married to a clerk. She has four children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for rent. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more bags of onions to sell

loans.name: Eam

texts.en:
Eam C., 40, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-angkorean temples. C. and her husband are farmers growing rice, earning an income of about $2.50 each per day to help cover the family expenses. 

C. is requesting a loan of $500 to repair her house. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to purchase more plots of farmland to grow more rice.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: repair house

loans.name: Ailarhon's Group

texts.ru:
Нынешние условия жизни диктуют новые условия, чтобы выжить и людям постоянно приходится подстраиваться под обстоятельства, чтобы вовремя прочувствовать, куда дует ветер. И сейчас люди в Кыргызстане трепетно ищут свою нишу, где человек наконец смог бы обрести сравнительный покой и заняться любимым делом и при этом вести достойную жизнь. Айлархон Борубаева – лидер данной группы. Айлархон сорок пять лет. Вот уже который день она встаёт спозаранку, накидывает на себя платок идёт в сарай, для дойки коров. При этом её обычная работа – преподавание английского языка в местной школе. Но пятнадцать лет назад она, вместе с мужем закупили живность и начали заниматься животноводством, а именно разведением крупнорогатого скота и реализацией молока. На сегодняшний день у Айлархон имеется три дойные коровы и три тёлки. Это занятие приносит ей пять тысяч сомов, что само по себе является довольно хорошей заработной платой в сельской местности. У Айлархон четверо детей. Старшая дочь учится в университете, а средняя недавно вышла замуж. Младшая дочь находится дома и помогает Айлархон по хозяйству, а саамы младший сын работает на стройке. Айлархон обратилась за этим кредитом, так как планирует купить одну тёлку на откорм. В ближайшем будущем ей надо накопить достаточно средств на ремонт дома, и надо также выдать двух дочерей замуж и закупить мебель. Айлархон понимает, что надо работать и продолжать трудиться. 
Партнёры Айлархон по группе:
Гайратбеку Пиратову тридцать пять лет. Гайратбек уже десять лет занимается откормом и перепродажей быков. Он три месяца откармливает бычков, а затем реализует их на скотном рынке. У Гайратбека растут трое детей и поэтому ему надо увеличивать доход, чтобы покрывать растущие расходы семьи. Гайратбеку нужен кредит, чтобы купить тёлку для разведения. 
Тилляхан Сарматовой сорок три года. Она – мать троих детей. Для Тилляхан самое главное это вырастить детей и помочь встать им на ноги. На данный момент она занимается животноводчтвом и выращиванием кукурузы. Она уже на пенсии. Получив этот кредит она хочет купить тёлку.
Суюмкуль Юсуповой сорок семь лет. Суюмкуль занимается откормом и перепродажей скота. У Суюмкуль четверо детей. Старшие дети уже работают, младшему сыну всего пять лет. Суюмкуль понимает, что любое дело требует постоянных инвестиций и вложений. Она хочет получить кредит и купить корову с телёнком. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
Life is ever-changing and people have to be constantly aware of their present circumstances to be prepared for when the winds change. Now, people in Kirgizstan are in an avid search for a haven, where they could lead a quality life while working their dream job. Ailarhon B. is the leader of this group. She’s forty-five years old and she begins her day at sunrise milking the cows. It is worthy to note, that her day job is teaching English at a local school. But fifteen years ago, together with her husband, she bought some livestock and began to breed cattle -- raising and milking it. Today her flock includes three heifers and three milking cows. This business brings in about five thousand soms a month, which is a very decent income in the countryside. Ailarahon has four children. Her oldest daughter is studying at a university, her middle one just got married, and her youngest daughter helps her mother around the house and with the business. Her youngest child – her son – works construction. Ailrahon is asking for a loan, because she plans to expand her business and buy another cow. In the near future she needs enough resources to fix up her house, buy new furniture and marry off her daughters. She understands that this will involve dedication and constant work. She has three partners in the group: Gairatbek P. is thirty-five years old, and the last ten of them he has fattened and sold livestock. He buys a bull, fattens it for about three months, and then resells it at the livestock market. He has three growing children, and so he needs to increase his income if he wants to meet the growing needs of his family. With the loan, he would buy a heifer to raise more cattle. Tillyahan S. is forty-three years old and a mother of three children. Her main objective in life is to raise her children and help them get a good start in life. She’s retired right now and raises livestock and corn for a living. She’s asking for a loan to buy another cow. Suyumkul U. is forty-seven years old. She also fattens and sells cattle for profit. She has four children, the oldest of which are already working, and the youngest is five years old. Suyumkul understands that any business requires investment and dedication. She’s requesting a loan to buy a cow and a calf.

Translated from Russian by Alex Kostrubsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to purchase a calf for breeding
